text: On tap at Arrow and Loon. Pours an average size frothy beige head but goes away pretty quick. Has a fairly cloudy amber appearance. Dirty lacing. Aromas of yeast, oranges, earthy hops. Flavours are very fruity, some oranges and even peaches, also quite yeasty. Pretty good mouthfeel.

Draft to taster
Fruit, flower, yeast. Light amber, thin white head. Taste is fruity and yeasty.
Draft - Light grains, some perfume aromatics and a touch of spice. Cloudy brown with a decent beige head. Grains, light yeasty sweetness an eatery finish.
Huge head on this...well the can pretty much exploded on me. Seriously though amazing beer. I hope this becomes part of their regular line up, or at least a seasonal.

[7234-20150518] Tap. Mild grainy soured fruit aroma. Slightly hazy, dark brown amber body with a medium-lasting creamy off-white head. Boozy fruity malt flavour with a long aftertaste. Medium body. Good. (7/3/7/3/14) 3.4
(Brewers Backyard @ Brickworks, Toronto, ON)

Malty, herbal hoppy and serious with frothy head and cloudy pale coat. Mineral and very soft pisce. Wow! Lemon backing and alco warmth is not harsh. Masterful palate is king of creamy and lightly sharp at the same time, tastes true to style. Unexpectedly matured.
Tap. Clear copper amber, thin beige head, good lacing. Nice malty aroma, bit of spice and yeast. Flavour is nice and spicy as well.

Can from the brewery. Clear dark copper with a huge tan head that hangs around and leaves tons of lace. Big fruity nose with banana, and plums with candy and lots of yeasty spice. Flavour is sweet fruit with bread and nuts. sweetness is tempered well with a light bitterness and pepper. Medium mouth with soft carbonation and a lingering finish. Enjoyable.

2015-05-18. Hazy red brown body with a moderate creamy beige head. 3+ Aroma is fruity and lightly alcoholic. Flavour has a sweet core, lightly bitter up front, fruit and hops, bitterness modest alcohol presence. Smooth average bodied palate, soft carbonation. Nice. On tap at Brewers Backyard, Toronto.
Fruit hazy flavour. Spot on biere de garde flavour. At brewers backyard. Medium mouthfeel. Lacy.

473 mL can. Pours burnished amber with a thick head of white foam. Big fruit on the nose, banana bread, candi sugar, fig, date, over ripe apple. Mild earthy must on the finish. A big wallop of alcohol on the back end and lots of carbonation keep it from getting cloying. Very dry, only a hint of caramel sweetness. Big on body and sticky on the palate.

473ml can at Brothers Beer Bistro. Clear copper with a huge everlasting frothy off-white head. Flavors are cereals, caramel, dried fruits, citrus, mint and spices with earthy, herbal and floral notes. Medium body, lively carbonation, slick texture.

On tap at the "Lanc" - tap fills the glass with a lightly hazed dark copper-red ale with a billowing 3 finger off white cap that laces well. Aroma is subtle when cold but pungent as it warms - a complex malt signature and light herbal tones. Character is sturdy, malty, silken delivery, - Flavor profile gives you a big whack in the teeth with complex maltiness then good balance - rich, nutty, bready, woodsy, minutely sweet then the long drying finish is clean, toasty and increasingly bitter with a great hop bite at the end - Wow , what a smooth drinker for such a big ale - I have no idea how his got branded as a bier de guard because this is the best Dopple Sticke Alt flavor I have tasted outside LTM and Beaus double altbiers I wish this was available all year.

Im pretty sure this is the first of its style that Ive had. First impression leans on Belgium style rock candy sugar ale. Pours a dark teak with a lush cappuccino foam style cap. One of the prettier beers you will see, sustains its head & gives off lacing like a politician handing out tax breaks before an election. 

Note the highly tweaked carbonation. Note the snap & crackle coming out of the glass, you can almost hear it from across the table. Comes on malty, with more sugar on the tongue than a last chance dance at last call. Finish is herbal, peppery & slightly boozy. I dig the bite, not so hip to the candy sweetness, but again Im working blind with this style & appreciate this as an educational experience (esecislly at 8.5%). Great winter beer, even if Im drinking this in early April up here at the cabin on the lake.

A dark brown pour with explosive head. A rich amber colour gives way to a full bodied flavour. The alcohol is not hidden here as it warms you up quickly. A nice change from flavoured winter beers. Would be perfect after snow blowing the driveway.

Tap at Cheshire Cat. Pours brown with lots of head and lacing. Nose is sweet and yeasty. Flavours are syrup, cheerios and some plums. Taste light sweet, light bitter. Light body with light carbonation.

Pours super foamy with a amber colour. Yeasty estery kitchen spice a nutmeg dominate the aroma with a touch of alcohol. More of the same on the palate, belgian yeast esters with nutmeg and spice. Peppery with a bit of fruit juice finish. Very tasty stuff.
En fût au Brothers. Ambré. Très épicé. Fruits séchés. Noisette. Très Levuré. Boisé. Écorce d'orange. Coriandre. Bien.
On tap at Bent Elbow. Caramel aroma. Belgian spice and caramel taste, with a fair bit of booze. Pretty tasty.

Can - 473ml. Limpid copper body with a thick, off-white foamy head. Decent malty/hoppy aroma with herbal and woody hints. Alcohol is well hidden. Its well balanced, fresh malty/hoppy taste carries herbal notes and ends with a good bitter/herbal finish. OK.

Where and how:  on tap at Volo 
Aroma fruit with hint of cherry, mild tartness. Engaging aroma. 7+
 Appearance : 
Top: neatly contrasting white top. Presentable.
Base: fine haze on dark amber.
Palate :  approachable, clean, flawless.
Taste: cherry like tartness, hint of smoke. Nice mild carbonation.
 other notes  easy to drink, could have few pints of this goodness.

Can from the brewery. Dark amber pour, medium to large off white head. Dry bready, yeasty malty aroma, subtle fruit, with some dry grassy hops. Mouth feel is nice, subtle carb. Finish is dry, yeasty, with some nice ripe fruit, and slight warming alcohol.
Jan. 30, 2015. In Januarys Brew Box. Can. Caramel colour with white fluffy head. Caramel, toffee, biscuit aromas. Honey, toffee, caramel and biscuit flavours.

On tap at Volo. Pours a lightly hazed dark amber with moderate-sized cream-coloured head. Aroma is spicy and herbal with some caramel, bright fruit and grain notes. Flavour is sweetish caramel, with tree fruit, graininess and a sort of peppery spiciness. Fine carbonation. Solid.

A hazed murky dark reddish amber Saison with a thin lacing off white head. In aroma, sweet fruity caramel malt with light spices, banana, curacao, orange pulp, very nice and smooth. In mouth, a nice sweet fruity malt orange pulp, banana, cloves, coriander, curacao, very Belgian and pleasing. On tap at Arrow and Loon.

On tap at the Arrow and Loon. 
Appearance: Pours a hazy dark brown with a finger of off white head. Average retention and lots of lacing.
Aroma:Belgian yeast, grains
Flavours:Belgian yeast, cereal.
 Mouthfeel: Average mouthfeel with a nice dry finish and low carbonation. 
Overall: Nice ale with distinct Belgian characteristics. Lots of layers of flavour and aroma.

Tap at Bar Hop. Deep amber pour with a very thick white head. The nose is slightly sweet with a sort of herbal hop aroma. A touch of spicy hoppiness but more grassy and herbaceous as well. A fairly caramelly malt base with some light peppery alcohol and a bit of toast. Theyve come very close to nailing the style.

Sampled at Barhop. Light mahogany with tan head. Cereal maltiness with a nice prominent yeast profile, somewhat boozy, light spice, moderate carbonation and full bodied, slightly bitter and becomes more so as it dries it and resiny hops come out.
